title: Choreo Homepage
heading: Choreo Home
content: Choreo Homepage allows users to select, create, delete, or manage Choreo projects. A Choreo project s a collection of Choreo components

title: Choreo Project Page
heading: Choreo Project Page
content: This page allows users to select, create, delete, or manage Choreo components. This is the overview of a Choreo project, where users can list the components belonging to a particular project

title: Choreo Component Page
heading: Choreo Component Page
content: The component overview page allows users to look at the details of an existing component such as the latest GIT commit, deployment status, and business metrics. Moreover, users can rename the component and add labels and a description to the component using this view

title: Deploy Choreo Component
heading: Deploy Choreo Component
content: Choreo deployment view allows users to deploy their components. Users can first deploy the component to the development environment, and then promote it to the production environment after the testing. Moreover, users can enable/disable the automatic deployment of the component after each commit that edits its implementation.

title: Test Choreo Component
heading: Open API Console
content: This Choreo test view let users test their deployed APIs using the integrated OpenAPI console

title: Test Choreo Component
heading: cURL
content: This Choreo test view let users test their deployed APIs using the cURL command

title: Test Choreo Component
heading: postman
content: This Choreo test view let users test their deployed APIs by integrating Postman with Choreo

title: Manage Choreo API
heading: Overview
content: The overview of the Manage page gives you a bird's eye view of how you currently manage your API component. You can view the lifecycle status of your component, the number of consumers, the security scheme configured, and the usage plan applied to the API. The Overview pane also lists the environment(s) of the API.

title: Manage Choreo API
heading: Lifecycle
content: Choreo allows you to manage the lifecycle of the API through the Choreo Console. A state represents the stage of an API in the process from creation to retirement. You can apply any of the six API lifecycle states (i.e.,Created, Pre-released, Published, Blocked, Deprecated, and Retired) while adhering to their respective lifecycle flows. When you publish an API, you can also publish a connector for that API to make it available on the Choreo Marketplace.

title: Manage Choreo API
heading: Consumers
content: The Consumers pane shows us the applications that have subscribed to your API. You can manage access to your API by blocking or unblocking these applications through the Choreo Console. The Consumers pane lists the applications, and for each application, it shows the usage tier, owner, and status: blocked or unblocked.

title: Manage Choreo API
heading: Documents
content: API documentation is vital in helping API consumers understand the functionality of your API and is beneficial to marketing the API. The Choreo Console allows you to add a document on the fly by entering a name and the API contents. You can also preview the document and verify if it is suitable for publishing.

title: Manage Choreo API
heading: Lifecycle
content: You can secure your API backends by applying rate-limiting policies through the Usage Plans pane.

title: Manage Choreo API
heading: Permissions
content: Permissions allow you to attach scopes that enable fine-grained access control to your API resources. You can create a scope entry by giving a scope name. You can then select and apply these scopes to the individual resources in your API. On the identity provider, a scope will have a role mapped to it. A role specifies the permissions associated with it. When you invoke the API resource with a specific scope, the access to your API resource is controlled based on the permissions associated with the role.
